bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Aristides Agramonte, August 22, 1929

div1.p: Kean inquires about Agramonte's father and explains the delay of Agramonte's medal and pension, approved in February 1929.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Aristides Agramonte, August 22, 1929
div1.opener:
22 August, 1929.
Dr. Aristides Agramonte,
Calle K, Entre 15 y 17,
Vedado, Habana, Cuba.
My dear Dr. Agramonte:
div1.p:
I have just been reading in the Cuban Boletin del
Ejercito an account of the death of Major General Ignacio
Agramonte who was killed at Jimaguayu, May 11, 1873. I
have the impression that he was your father and would like
to know if this is correct. If not, what was his relation
to you and what was your father's name and rank when he was
killed in battle?

I hope you will not be impatient over the long time
before you get your medal and pension. The money for them
has to be included in an appropriation bill approved by the
Office of the Budget and passed some time next winter. The
pension, however, will, as I understand it, begin from the
passage of the act, February 28, 1929.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, J. R. KEAN
Colonel, U.S. Army, Retired
Editor. JRK/W
